results.title: Forced into images
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour, silent
results.brief_description: In Destiny Deacon’s photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds that follows a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood. Deacon’s work often explores cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Indigenous women.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

results.description: DESTINY DEACON has shown in exhibitions including the 2001 Yokohama Triennale, Das Lied von der Erde at the Museum Fridericianum in Kassel, the 2000 Biennale of Sydney and the 1995 Havana Biennial and the Yokohoma triennial. Using people and objects close to her - friends and family, dolls and other toys - the artist creates strange, unsettling images that address some of the most difficult aspects of contemporary Australian life. Cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Aboriginal women all inform Deacon’s photography, and her gift for storytelling and biting sense of humour provide her work with a compelling edge. With her photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds, following a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood.
description_for_label: DESTINY DEACON has shown in exhibitions including the 2001 Yokohama Triennale, Das Lied von der Erde at the Museum Fridericianum in Kassel, the 2000 Biennale of Sydney and the 1995 Havana Biennial and the Yokohoma triennial. Using people and objects close to her - friends and family, dolls and other toys - the artist creates strange, unsettling images that address some of the most difficult aspects of contemporary Australian life. Cultural stereotyping, domestic violence and the status of Aboriginal women all inform Deacon’s photography, and her gift for storytelling and biting sense of humour provide her work with a compelling edge. With her photographic series Forced into Images (a title taken from a poem by Alice Walker), a dramatic narrative unfolds, following a girl’s troubled life from birth to womanhood.

results.title: Telephone technique
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau, Wesley Greene and Crawley Films
results.brief_description: Part of a series on sales training, this episode deals with telephone training for retail sales clerks. It emphasizes good telephone manners, wide knowledge of stock, importance of correct customer name and address and the necessity for an intelligent descriptive vocabulary when speaking of merchandise over the telephone.

results.title: Bushland fantasy
results.creator_credit: Soundmasters and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Provides glimpses of the many wild flowers and animals found in the Australian bush. Includes photographs of native flora, and animal life such as kangaroos, wallabies, platypus, lyrebirds and koalas. Many of these can be found in the wildlife sanctuary at Healesville where special efforts are made to arrange a proper diet for these animals. Narrated by John Dudley.

results.title: Behind the menu
results.brief_description: A survey of the use of gas in commercial cooking and industrial establishments. The film includes glimpses of what happens “behind the menu” at establishments like the Menzies Hotel, The Royal Melbourne Hospital, the canteen at General Motors and a biscuit factory.

results.title: Here's your bike, Ed!
results.creator_credit: Steve Westh, John Taylor, Taylormade Films and Vic Roads
results.brief_description: The purpose of this title is to demonstrate a variety of skills that children need to cycle safely on roads. Designed to accompany a Bike Ed program in schools, with Teacher’s notes, there are a variety of activities and drills which will develop children’s confidence as bike riders and users of the road.

results.title: Timber
results.brief_description: A survey of the forests from which Australia obtains timber supplies for firewood, building and other industrial purposes. Illustrates tree-felling and the various methods used to transport logs to timber-mills. Overviews the preservation of natural forests and revegetation programs.

results.title: The Greatest Art Movement: Transporting Art: the Story of Melbourne's Art Trams
results.creator_credit: Michael Buckley, National Heart Foundation of Australia. Victorian Division and Arts Victoria
results.brief_description: Trams have always been a feature of Melbourne life and they have now been transformed into moving art galleries. Melbourne’s Transporting Art Project involves a new series of decorated trams. Several of the artists discuss their reasons for taking part in the scheme, the themes behind their work and the unusual medium. Artists include Aleks Danko, Philip Faulks, Lin Onus, Terry Matassoni, Jenny Watson and Brett Colquhoun.
results.title_for_label: The Greatest Art Movement: Transporting Art: the Story of Melbourne’s Art Trams
